text:
Tourism Noosa fudges tourism figures to look attractive
Tourism Noosa has been accused of fudging its visitor statistics in a bid to look more attractive than its rival holiday destinations in Queensland.
Industry leaders have called for transparency amid revelations the tourism body beefed up the iconic town’s domestic and overseas tourist numbers.
Tourism Noosa has been publicising visitor growth beyond most other regions, including the Gold Coast and the rest of the Sunshine Coast.
But tourism chiefs say they don’t trust the numbers because Noosa had been including areas outside its boundaries.
A Tourism Research Australia (TRA) review found the normally parochial town was adding visitor data from tourism hotspots in the neighbouring Sunshine Coast Council.
When questioned last week, a Tourism Noosa spokesperson admitted to including Coolum and Eumundi figures, claiming those areas were previously under its umbrella, but said it ended the practice in March.
The discovery has raised suspicions about the veracity of Noosa’s holiday data as it sells itself as the state’s leading growth market.
Claims that international spending in the town soared to $142.3 million in the year to March – more than doubling from $69.4 million in 2013 – are now being rubbished as unreliable and unrealistic.
A closer look at the latest international figures reveals a 10 percent drop in visitors to Noosa Heads offset by a 50 per cent rise in tourists to Noosaville in 2014-15, equating to a 18.8 per cent overall increase.
Sunshine Coast Destination boss Simon Ambrose said he was concerned his northern neighbour’s assertions were misleading.
“We are also concerned, when they make negative comments about the rest of the Sunshine Coast, because we should all be in this together,” Mr Ambrose said.
A Tourism Noosa spokesperson said the body was “reporting on facts and data that is accessed directly from the TRA database via an economic consultant, EMDA, and growth data is consistent with figures provided directly by TRA”.
